docs.lead_paragraph: Portugal's Espirito Santo family business survived wars, dictatorship, revolution and family feuds for almost 150 years. Now, one of Europe's last banking dynasties is being stripped of its wealth and influence amid accounting irregularities, huge unreported debts, record losses at the family bank and a police investigation.

headline.main: Bank Scandal Tarnishes Powerful Portuguese Family
headline.print_headline: Bank Scandal Tarnishes Powerful Portuguese Family

docs.lead_paragraph: The House overwhelmingly approved a landmark bill Wednesday to help veterans avoid long waits for health care that have plagued the Veterans Affairs Department for years.

headline.main: House Approves VA Health Care Overhaul
headline.print_headline: House Approves VA Health Care Overhaul

docs.lead_paragraph: A survey from the Kaiser Foundation said many previously uninsured Californians had been able to get coverage, through either Medicaid or private insurers.

headline.main: More Californians Sign Up for Health Plans, Survey Says, but Holdouts May Be Hard to Get
headline.print_headline: More Californians Sign Up for Health Plans, Survey Says, but Holdouts May Be Hard to Get

docs.abstract: Survey by Kaiser Family Foundation shows that nearly six out of 10 uninsured people in California were able to obtain coverage in past year; findings highlight difficulties signing up individuals who remain uninsured, even with emergence of new state marketplaces.
docs.snippet: A survey from the Kaiser Foundation said many previously uninsured Californians had been able to get coverage, through either Medicaid or private insurers.

docs.lead_paragraph: In New York, Mayor Bill de Blasio's negotiations with municipal workers’ unions are focusing on expanded use of walk-in clinics and other cost-saving measures.

headline.main: De Blasio’s Plans to Reduce Worker Health Costs Have a Carrot and a Stick
headline.print_headline: De Blasio’s Plans to Reduce Worker Health Costs Have a Carrot and a Stick

docs.abstract: More use of walk-in clinics and generic drugs and fewer emergency-room visits are envisioned in New York City Mayor Bill de Blasio’s first labor agreements with city unions; if city and unions are unable to save $3.4 billion on health care by 2018, mediator will be empowered to order increases in workers' premiums.
docs.snippet: In New York, Mayor Bill de Blasio's negotiations with municipal workers’ unions are focusing on expanded use of walk-in clinics and other cost-saving measures.

docs.lead_paragraph: There are historic examples that point to reasons for worry in the current contract dispute between 15 unions and the Met.

headline.main: Labor Struggles at Metropolitan Opera Have a Past
headline.print_headline: Labor Struggles at Opera Have a Past

docs.abstract: Metropolitan Opera is facing one of its worst labor crises in years, with general manager Peter Gelb threatening to lock out orchestra, chorus and workers if they do not agree to new contract; conflict reflects opera's history of labor disputes, many of which left scars that lasted long after agreements were reached.
docs.snippet: There are historic examples that point to reasons for worry in the current contract dispute between 15 unions and the Met.

docs.lead_paragraph: The settlement brings a significant change in the care and safety of current and former college athletes, including a $70 million medical monitoring fund and a new national protocol for head injuries.
docs.abstract: NCAA reaches preliminary settlement in class-action lawsuit brought by former college athletes; brings significant change in the care and safety of all current and former college athletes, including a $70 million medical monitoring fund and a new national protocol for head injuries; does not provide financial compensation for injuries but allows for individual players to sue for damages.
docs.snippet: The settlement brings a significant change in the care and safety of current and former college athletes, including a $70 million medical monitoring fund and a new national protocol for head injuries.

docs.lead_paragraph: A 2009 law that raised federal taxes to discourage smoking cost the U.S. government billions of dollars in lost revenue as manufacturers relabeled products and consumers shifted to cheaper pipe tobacco and large cigars, the U.S. Government Accountability Office said in a report released on Tuesday.
